div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

p.hi: Public Analyst for the City of Glasgow and the Counties of Lanark, Renfrew, &c.

div.p: N.B.—This Whisky is the same as supplied to the Red Cross Society, London, to the House of Lords and House of Commons.

div.head: THE LAW OR THE LEAGUE ?
div.p: If the Present Government succeed in living out any ng the allotted span of Ministérial “existence, says the “Pall Mall Gazette”, they ought to succeed in Jeaving behind them a remarkable collection of what “Mr. Panch” thas described as “things one would rather not have said.” The pidus founder.and most gen8rous benefactor of that Maseum ‘is,’ ot course, the Prime Minister, ‘Time was when the “blazing indiscretions” of thelate Lord Salisbury used occasionally 1» astonish both his friends and his foes. But Lord Salisbury was always wise, and often witty ; and, if he was. somewhat given - to thinking. aloud, he never spoke without ‘thinking. Not so our own good Sir Henry. “Methods of barbarism” and “sqvalid bonds” are fair specimens of the sort of thing which his supporters periodically find themselves © compelled to explain away, as they haye lately ~ tried to do with his charge of blank refusal of applications to landlords for small holdings, and as they were trying’ to do yesterday, and the day before, i. the Lords with regard to the “very satisfietory” state of Ireland.. And; as with the Premier, so with other members of the Government-and party. Now there is some delicate personal allusion, or pies? more picturesque than polite phraseology by the Under-Secretary for the Colonies : anon we have Mr. Birrell and his “carrion crows.” Yesterday it was the torn of Lord Denman, who, in an evil hour, had been put up to answer Lord. Londonderry, and thought proper to excise the offence of cattle-driving as not being in the eyes of the Govérnment, “a crime of a very serious natare.” We yenture to say that this is a specimen well worthy of a glass all to itselfin the Memorial Museam of the Ministry of Allthe Mistakes. It is quite the most mischievous—and gratuitously mis- chievous—thing said by Minister, or on the Ministerial behalf, since "methods of bar- barism,” becduse, like that classic phrase, it will encourage the foeg. and discourage the friends, of England, the of whom, in this case, are not the Boers, but the’ disloyal and lawless lrishry. By this time, as we do not doubt, every newspaper in ile Nationalist and.Unionist, is spreading far and. wide the news that the Government do not consider the action which is making’ life intolerable . on nearly two hundred and fifty grazing farms to be “a crime of a very serious natare.” Well, everything is relative ; is not murder, ‘or arson, or “cat ‘iming—though it may well lead ee three. But it is a form of intimi tely planned for the ruin of two whole pe of the King’s subjects, the landlords who have lawfully let their land, and the graziers who have lawfully taken it. ‘To say that organized and violent interference with the rights of these men is not a crime of serious nature is the negation of law{and order—it is nothihg less than the justification of anarchy.

It goes, of course, without saying that the Government had-to explain away Lord Den- man : no amount of tenderness for the cattle- drivers could blind either Lord Crewe or Lord Ripon to the necessity of declaring that Min- igters were firmly determined to put down disorder. The law, said Lord Ripon, will be ined without fear or favour. We hope it will ; but, so far, it has not been sufficiently efficacious to prevent, Lord Lansdowne stated, the surrender of thirty farms in Roscommon within the past few weeks. There is, however, an aspect of the Irish situation which law- abiding often fail to appreciate, simply because it is quite alien to any personal experience of their own. It may be confidently asserted that the real measurs of the terrorisu: exercised by the United Irish League, like that of the Camorra in Southern Italy, is not tobe ascertained from the statistics of outrages actually committed. When a policy of terrorism has been entered upon, and when the beliet is general, alike among the terrorists atid their victims, . that!the Irish Government is not dis- posed to deal severely with offenders, the need for what the Frencly revolutionaries call “'ac- tion directe” is very considerably diminished. When the prospective victims of agrarian Outrage are well aware that prosecutions are bound to fail, that magistrates will not sum- marily convict, and that it is hopeless to expect justice at the hands of local juries what i4 open to them except surrender! That we have not the slightest doubt, is the true inwardness of the comparative tranquil- ie of. fitietaiots in which it is notorions that the League is omnipotent, History is, in fact, repeating itselfin Ireland, with no perceptible variation, at the* present time.” The United Trish League is playing the game of the old Land -League, its own true begetter, in pre- cisely the Land League's old way. And, as might be expected, it is not on that side alone that the historical parallel is being drawn with geometrical accuracy. The present Liberal Government is merely giving the old answers to the old. questions, and with the old results. Things are, in consequence, going from bad to worse, as they went a generation ago, and the time is rapidly coming when even Mi Birrell will be compelled to make up his mind whether Ireland is to"be ruled by the King’s ‘Government or by. that of the United Irish League. That, assuredly, is the way events are trending, back through the old course of crime to the inevitable dilemma—the law of the League? Which is it going to be?

div.head: Lechat Ganem Assault Case.
div.p: Judgement was given yesterday morning in the above case, which has become so prominent and has caused so much speculation during the past few days. It was decided that freat provo- cation had been given for the attack and, in consequence, duly taking into consideration the opprobrious terms employed, Mr. Lechat was sentenced to two months imprisonment with the option to purchase his release at the rate of 3 francs for each day of confinement, or a total of 180 franc.

div.head: Fight with Police.
div.p: A serious quarrel occurred at Ras el TIn on Thursday evening, which resulted in a fight between a party of some twenty-five natives and the police. The natives in question went to a cafe of the kism and ordering several bottles of beer, commenced to fight each other with them. Upon the interference of the police their attention was directed towards overcoming the guardians of the peace. The struggle bewteen the disturbers and the police lasted, we are told, three hours and though the recalcitrants were finally arrested the police suffered considerable damage, while the Greek in charge of the cafe had his head cut open.

div.head: THE VEILED PROTECTORATE.
div.p: Referring to: our special cable of the.8th inst. “Al Watan” says :—

Our last article on this subject- has been quoted and diseussed by the Eurepean Press, Unfortunately the discussion was in the wrong direction owing to a mistake of the London paper which published a precis of our article wired by its Caifo correspondent. In that precis “I'he Globe” told therworld that we had applied for a British Protectorate thus neces- sitating enquiry into the source and effect of our quoted article and a subsequent outburst of heat and anger in the local National Press with its concomitants of misrepresentation and abuse. “Al Minbar” and other misinformed’ papers were full yesterday of deprecations and insmuations before waiting to ascertain the facts.. We have nothing new to say on the subject of the Veiled Protectorate beyond the fact that an error in transmission has led to a misunderstanding of our. views. In the article which gave rise to this discussion we repeatedly and plainly said that we do not apply for annexation or open protection, that we do not invite England to swallow our inde- pendence, and that we prefer a native Govern- ment, hoping that England will help us to gain our independence one day. All we desired and prayed for was a shift from the untenable position of temporary occupation which has been held too long, anend to the uncertainty of this unofficial and undecided form of Govern- ment which helps in creating trouble and gives a wide scope for seditious agitation. We explained that under the present circumstan- ces England had no right to remain in’ Egypt, that she“is here in the timid and hesitating manner of the guest who has overstayed his welcone. Unless the Veiled Protectorate was put ona more permanent footing, agitation will go on and the work of Government will become dangerous or perhaps impossible. This was the essence of ovr wrongly quoted article which had Mr. Dicey’s interview with the Khedive for its raison d’étre. In that interview his Highness gave expression to his views on'the Occupation and Protectorate ard opened the door-for public comments on the subject. We are sorry. that an erroneous transmission of our views has caused a misunderstanding, but we were not astonished at the venom of the Na- tionalist Press in Cairo, unprovoked and un- justified.

div.head: EGYPTS IMPORTS.
div.p: ‘The total value of the varioys imports which passed through the Customs during April was L.B2,243,950 or an increase of I.E. 585,098 ,over the same month last year. ‘The principal countries sharing in the additional shipments were Great Britain (LB. 200,000), France (L.E, 87,000), Austria (LE. 63,000), Turkey (LE. 60,000), and Italy (LE. 41,000). The clearances from Germany showed a,loss on the month of nearly LB. 11,000,

The lion’s share of the extra trade was credited to the Textile group where the expan- sion was over L.E. 191,000. The metal class was nearly L.E. 91,000 to the good, whilst coal wasup to the extent of L.E. 32,000. Spirits and oils were L.B. 41,000 higher than last year, and cereals showed increased deliveries amount- ing to LE. 29,000.
Brass, Copper and Bronzde Goods.
The returns at L.E. 39,400 were L.E. 20,600. above last year.. England did L.E. 24,000 and Francé 1.B. 199500.
Building Materials.
The marble and stone figures amounted to L.E. 8,700 being an iincrease of LE: 3,400. Italy forwarded I.E. 7,000 and Austria LE. 1000,
The value of the lime, plaster and cement delivered during: April was at LE. 14,600 trifle under the 1905 returns. France was responsible for L.E. 4,800, England L.E. 4,700 and Belgium L.E. 4,000.
Coal.
The quantity cleared during the month was 168,000 tons, or an increase of 17,000 tons. The average price per 1000 tons last April was LE, 899.7 against LE. 787.5 twelve months ago.
Flour.
The imports + were 14 1/2 million kilos against 11 millions last year. France sent flour to the value of L.E..78,500, Russia L.E.10,700, and England L.E. 10;600.
Furniture.

Compared with the corresponding month in 1906, the furniture returns for April at LE. 48,500 showed an increase of LE. 20,000. Austria cleared L.E. 12,600,. France LE. 12,200 whilst England took third place with LE. 9,800 Italy contributed L.E. 9,100.
Hoops.
The hoops landed during April weighed 175,942 kilos, and were valued at L.E. 1,460.
Iron and Iron goods.

The clearances classified by weight under this heading were 10,225 tons = L.E. 68,639, and by value LE 118,774. The former figures show an expansion of 819 tons, and the latter are LB. 23,000 to the good. England «was credited with L'E. 70,000, Belgium L.E.51,000 Germany L.E. 42,000 and France L.E. 11,700.
Linen Goods.
The main countries interested in the linen goods which arrived here during April were France L.E. 15,800, England L.E 12,500 and Austria LE. 8 600.
Locomotive and Rolling Stock.
Engines—probably all light Agricultural ones—to the value of L.E. 1,145 came over from Germany. These figures were the only ones entered under the heading “hocomotives.”
The rolling stock shipments of L.E. 28,500 were divided between England with L.E. 16,370 and Belgium LE. 12,130.
Manchester Goods.

For the goods classed by weight the returns were 1,665,000 kilos (L.E. 201,700) and by measure 4,656,000 metres (L.E. 84,900). Com- pared with April 1906, the above figures are increases of 275,000 kilos, 2,256,000 metres and L.B. 92,052 in total values.
Machinery-Agricultural.

The returns for April were close upon L.E. 26,000. England L.E. 16,800, Switzerland L.E 5,600 and France L.E. 1,785. Germany only figured for L.E. 349. The total clearances were L.E. 3,900. below those of 1905.
Machinery General.

Apart- from Agricultural machines, over L.E. 87,000 worth of"machinery reached Egypt during the month, being an increase of nearly L.B-A3,000. England contributed L.E. 43,000, France L.E. 16,800, Austria LE. 8,700 and Germany L.E. 6,100.
Rice.

The deliveries of rice during March were, as we stated last month, 9 1/2 millions kilos. For April they were barely 1 1/4 millions all from Rangoon—or a drop of 2 1/4 millions on the corresponding figures twelve months ago.
Sugar.
The shrinkage in the sugar discharges was nearly 2 million kilos, tha actual figures in kilos being 1,466,508 against 38,840,040 in 1906. Austria sent practically the ‘whole of the supply.
Sacks.
The deliveries of this article amounted to 846,000 kilos valued at L.E. 17,881 against 958,000 kilos=L.E. 18,122 last year.
Timber.
The deliveries of this article amounted to 846,000 kilos valued at L.E. 17,881 against 958,000 kilos=L.E. 18,122 last year.
England's Share.

Ont ofthe gross value of Egypt's imports during April viz : LE. 2,243,950, England was credited with L.E.'819,661 or 2 shade over 36 %. Her proportionof the country’s addition- al trade of LE. 585,098 was 38. 7% or LE. 207,078, mainly” due to heayy clear- ances of cotton and linen goods, : whilst coal, machinery, and woollen fabrics were well to.the fore. On the debit side of the account were shrinkages of LE. 8,000 in agricultoral machinery, LE 5,200 in locomotives and L.E. 8,300 in cotton yarns.
(Journal of the British Chamber of Commerce)

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan has sold his yacht “Lolo el Nil” to Suares Bey Mikail.

At the Coungil of Ministers held this morning at Ras el Tin Palace under the pre- sidency of the Prime Minister, the resignation of Johnson Pasha was accepted. It was also decreed that Boutros Pasha Ghali should act a3 Regent during the absence of H.H. the Khedive and until the return of Hassein Fakhry Pasha.
Mr. P. W. Machell has arrived at Alex- andria from Cairo,
Fakhry Pasha*has arrived at Alexandria from Cairo and will leave for Europe on the 28rd inst.
Miralai H.G.K. Matchett Bey lias been appointed commandant of the Khartoum district.
Miralai Ali Bey Zemfail has been appointed commandant ofthe Khedivial Guard.
A marriage has been arranged between Mr. K. M. Haddad and Miss Helena Schmeil, sister of Rachid Bey Schmeil the proprietor and editor of our contemporary “Al Bassir”.
The Rey. C. H. V. Gollmer, who’ took duty at All Saints’ Ramleh last summer, arrived in Alexandria last Tuesday, and is assisting at St. Mark’s Church.
The Reverend F. G. B. Hastings, Royal Navy, will preach at the 11 o’clock Parade Service to-morrow at H.B.M’s. Garrison Church of St. George, Mustapha Pasha.

Capt. Frank Talland, Quartermaster, retired list, late of the 20th Hssars, died at Lilac Grove, Beeston, Notts, on the 21st ult, aged 56. After more than 10 years’ service in the ranks, he was promoted Quartermaster, 20th Hussars, May, 1889; obtained the hon, tank of Captain in May. 1899, and retired on retired pay March, 1903. He served with the Frontier Field Force in the Soudan, 1985:86, being present at the action of Ginnis (medal with ‘clasp and Khedive’s ‘star).. For the last twelve years he had been employed on recruit- ing seryice at Nottingham.

A dinner party of 16 covers was given last night by the Austrian Consul at the New Khedivial Hotel, the guests being Comte Gyorgyey, Comte Bernstorff, Comte Kozie- brodzki, Baron and Baronne Hauser, Marquis and Marquise Gacoli, M. and Mme Alexandre de Zogheb, Baronne and Baron Felix de Menasce, M. and Mme Jacques Aghion, Mr. L. Stagni, Baron Hauser, Mr. De Probitzer.

Among those who left for Europe yesterday by the Messageries Maritimes mail boat ,were Col. Bernard Pasha, Daninos Pasha, Mr. and Mrs. Chekri Ganem, Mrs. Pinching, Mr. Le-. grand, Mr, Blanchard, Mr. Rodocanachi, and Mr. and Mrs, Ovadia.

The following visitors are staying at the Windsor Hotel :—Mr. ahan, Mr. Sion, Mr. D. Angel, Mr. L. Flaming, Mr. @. Portos, Mr. W. Sarayany, Baron Chedeuvre, Mr. M. Ber- | « ghime, Mr. B. On annonce de Paris que, par decision de la Chmabre syndicale des agents de change, les 200,000 actions novuvelles de Frs. 500, liberees de Frs. 250, du Credit Foncier Egytien, sont admises aux negociations de la Bourse au comptnant et a terme depuis le 5 Juin courant.
Par suite, le nombre des actions du Credit FOncier Egyptien negociables sur le marche parisien se trouve porte de 200,000 a 400,000.

M. Cyneiead in a circular’ letter, refuses to accept the resignation of the mayors declar- ing that their action is really directed against parliamentary regime and the Republic. He warns the Communes that they damage nobody ‘but themselves. He finally appeals to their patriotiim to withdraw their resignation. The letter has been generally returned unopened. (Reuter)

Severe earthquake shocks were felt'yesterday in Jamaica and in Valdivia (Chile). The troops at Port Royal rushed into: the open. 46 of ethem were injured: in the stampede, 11 of whom ‘seriously. 5° persons were killed in Valdivia and numerous houses destroyed. (R.)

At a secret meeting of the Duyia, M. Sto“| lypine fleclared that he would dissolve’ the Duma if they refuse the exclusion of 55 depu- ties who are conspirators, 16 of whom, will be tried. The debate was deferred until to-morrow. (Havas)
A wood-yard has been destroyed by fire. Phe loss totals a million francs. (Havas)
Lancashire beat Surrey by 76 runs, Essex beat oe by aninnings and 90 rans. (Renter)
"The Mayor, Mr Schmitz, has been convicted of extorting money from French restaurant keepers. (Reuter’)

General Botha atthe re-opening of Parlia- ment said that the Government was unalterably convinced that the presence of the Chinese was most hurtful to the interests of the/l'ransvaal: moreover, the supply of native labour exceeded the demand. (Reuter)

‘The Emperor yesterday attended the elimin- ating trials for today’s motor race for his Majesty's cup, which will take place in the vicinity of Hamburg. Several cars were wrecked and a chauffeur killed. (Reuter)
Result of the Emperor William’s Cup: Italian Fiat first and a Belgian car second (Reuter)
The Italian Nazzaro has won the interna- tional motor-ear race at Taunus (Havas)
The Red Cross Conference was received with acclamation and has referred to a committee an invitation to hold the conference in 1912 in Japan, (Reuter)
Lieutenant Hart has been: killed and two men injured owing to an explosion on” board a submarine at Portsmouth. (Reuter)
The King and Queen of Denmark have sail- ed for Cherbourg to pay’ an official visit to France. (Reuter)
M. Fallitres received the King and Queen of Denmark at Cherbourg. Cordial ‘toasts were d. In the afternoon the Sovereigns arrived at Paris. The population warmly wel- comed them. (Havas)

div.head: AEGYPTICA
A NEW WORK UPON ANCIENT EGYPTIAN RELIGION.
div.p: By Joseph Offord.

The first series of lectures delivered at the College of France, in Paris, upon thé founda- tion bequeathed, for the purpose by M. Micho- uis, was by M. Edward Naville, the well known Swiss Egyptologist, and director now for some years of the exploration at Deir-el-Bahari. It is fortunate for science that the opportunity of this course of lectures induced Mr. - Naville to set forth what ‘his knowledge enable to tell of the religion of the ancient Egyptians. It is now nearly 30 years ‘since he published a'translation of the “Sdlar Litany” and of the ‘Myth of Horns,” and he is the greatest living authority npon the “Book for the Dead” and all he has to say about Egyptian culture, worship and theology in the excellent little volumn pablished as part of theAnnals of the Musée Giumet,” by M. Ernest Leroux of Paris will be carefully studied.

M. Naville explains, in the preface that in the lectures /he has treated of the six most Important matters, whose developement ‘get forth the chief aspects of Egyptian religion, becautse the field is so vast, no complete study could be made in six addresses, or comprvesetl into 270 pages.

The first chapter is devoted to a diego of the origin of the ancient Egyptians, and tHe probability of the earlier civilisation they acquired being derived from Babylonia ; and the author sums-up his view on the first part of the subject by giving-it as -his opinion that the original popnlation, so far as any vestige of mankind” enabl@.us to come to a was of African origin and was ci ed by Asiatic invaders coming from Arabia, who had crossed the Red Sea and entered Nubia to the south.

By “African” as the type of the earliest Egyptian race known to us, M. Naville does not mean Negroid, but a white race now represented by the Berbers and Kabyles, and in late Egyptian times shown apon the monu- ments as tribes to the west of the Nile Valley, ealled Temenhon or Tehennoy. Thése the author connects with the old Anon, or Archer people, with whom fhe Horus invaders of the country, whose cliief emblem was: (or whose greatest tribe — for emblem) a falcon fought and conquered. As to whether the Anon Were sufficiently civilised ‘to reside ‘in cities Me Naville is uncertain, but points ont that Aii, the earliest name*for Heliopolis, is. the, first half of their namé and that it was at that point that’ the conqueror’s first established any metropolitan religious centre, probably-an old Anou town,

That the conquerors who: introduced the arts and culturé to the first inhabitants came from the sotith into Egypt, M. Naville thinks proved by the universal testimony of the myths of the Horus invaders coming fron the South, and from the fact that an Egyptian when

oriéntating hinhself always looked: ito the South. But this latter postare is valso tachtigithe sun, and-facing the region where the beneficent Nile god was stationed|\and so the argument here appears weak.

‘The introdaction of the vine, the horse ant the camel; the author ascribes to later invasions orintroductions from Asia by way of Palestine and. the Delta, but the camel has béen found earved upon extremely ancight specimens of sculpture. Because such a Pharaoh as Rameses Il, desiring to trace-back his royal ancestors to the utmost limit, stops at Menes, and every list of early monarchs wepossess does the same.

With reference to the Babylonian origin of Egyptian: civilisation M. Naville says * “I do “not believe that. Bgypt is a daughter ot “Babylon, ‘but on the other hand we can quite “admit-they are both connected with Arabia; “it -was ‘the common origin: which accounts “for + ‘the analogies - between the two”.

Wi d_ respect for the erudition of. Mr. Naville, this does not explain the striking fact that the Mene’s.dynasty introduced into Egypt the use of the Babylonian cylinder as a signet, 4(form not}Arabian or very suitable for the Nilotie'people!whose documents were upon stone, leather or papyris, and except for the jar sealings and so called funeral cones not of clay.

‘The use of these cones is also absolutely identical with the practice, at 'Telloh and else where near tothe Persian Gulf. Moreover an extremely ancient drawing upon a small relic discoyered by Mr.de Morgan at Tejloh shows @ boat, or sacred barque, with similar Totem poles, supporting, a Caput bovis, to those of carly Egyptian pottery.

There is also a probability that these divine emblems are alluded to in old cuneiform texts as being placed at the entrance, to Mes mian temples ; just as they are shown in front of the primitive temple pylons, upon the drawings of the divine processional barques described. by Mr. Foncart.

M. Alfred Boissier in his “Pextes Rélatifs a la Divination Assyro-Babylousene,” refers to a word “Surinnu” which Mr. Thureau Dargin has praved means emblem, guidown, rallying post, or flagstaff: Dr. Lehmann has shown that these poles, or pillars were erected in front of temples. The very old inscriptions of king Gudea of Telloh, in Maritime Babylonia speak of them. Some of them “shone like the. light” and were coated with gold or silyer. In the old Cuneiform /Astrologicrl, or augural, reports, a portent of dire disaster was the destruction of these Surirmu. Mr. Boissier renders the word by “emblem,” perhaps: Totem would he quite as precise.
M. Calice has pointed out that the old Egyptian ‘word’ ‘‘nemset” for'a certain class of vase, is the “namsa” of the ‘I'el-el-Amarna ta- blets andjgoes back to the old Babylonian “namzitu.”

M. Henzly has shown an identical peouliarity of ornamentation in one of the Egyptian pre- historic slatepalettes anda Babylonian cylinder engraving, consisting of elongating the heads of animals. We must wait until excavations upon the littoral of the Persian Gulf and at | the island of Bahrein have diselosed to us the Maritime Babylonians and Elamites and their reli. ‘The X. chapter of Genesis, the oldest ethnographical survey in the ‘world a Persian Cush with an Ethiopic Cush, an Asian and African identity of race separated by the Arabian sea, the very regionfrom which M. Naville says Egyptian culture came; and the secret of the similarities between Egyptian and Babylonian culture most likely lies that way.

We are of course only speaking of Semitic, or Mésopotamian analogies upon Egyptian antiquities, undoubtedly dating prior to the Hyksos kings, or even the early dynasty con- nection with Syria at the Sinaitic peninsula. In later times Asiatic styles would be attri- butable to intercourse via Syria if found in Egypt. (3)

The second chapter discusses the different modes of Sepultnre in early times, and the evidence from burial relies as to the belief in a future life. M. Naville considers that the numerous tombs, or ground burials, having the ‘deceased arranged with the knees drawn up to the chest, is not imitation of the posi- tion of the unborn child indicative ofa new birth to come ; but merely the sitting - upow the hand with knees drawn up was just. the action of the hunter in his hnt returned from the chase. So his limbs were arranged thus after death, only the corpse was necessarily laid upon its side. Certainly many funerary statues exhibit the deceased in this attitude. Another suggestion is in regard to the elabor- ate tomb, or Mastaba, reliefs,hich show the person in whose honor the. sépulchré’ was ornamented furnished with many servants, and much cattle, fields, and orchards, yine- yards-and boats. M. Naville says that’ this does not-necessarily indicate that the owner of the gravé enjoyed. such opulence and broad domains on earth : but ix what it is hoped he will possess An the world to tome. The relief: scenes.aretn fact ; just as the ushabti figtrings were, if the requisite formulae were properly

(3) In Herr J, Welssenbori's valuable work ““Tierkult in Africa. Bine Ethnologisch, Bullurhistonsche Untersuchung”, he says “The ancient religion of ried of twoelementa. The autochthonous negrold populat! im, had been subjugated by smi tribe coming from Asia, To the amnalyatnation of two racempras duea religion, in which, whilst preserving inal beliefs; they sought to make them Ngree with the moots of thelr Conquerors. They asdimilated te ‘animal emer tothe polydeniontam of the Asfities, peortata goda of which. they; Heatime fle aymbula,” hia igfoss with the eribstokogical ivitunge fer" Mane took: od Tindall write ‘The population of anctent it two strangely by contrasted setsof physical features, vig,
recited and inscribed ensurers of the possession of slaves and seryants.in the next world. The meany Of granting to the‘dereased a complete ‘estaté in the future.

There is‘tio. reason to doubt that the number ‘of Ushabti fighres frequently exceeded the establishment, of servanta employed by the departed owners of the'tomb in which they were placed; and so may the quantity of animals and fowl, of groves and pasturages upon the Mastaba walls. In this chapter in describing the future life M: Navillecomments npon the varionssacred: books relating thereto, such as the Book of the Am-Suat and’ the nether world portions jof the pyramid texts.

div.p: ORDINARY GENERAL MEETING
TO BE HELD AT
THE NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT,
on Saturday, June 22nd, 1907
At 4 o'clock, p.m.

NOTICE- IS HEREBY GIVEN that the ANNUAL-~ ORDINARY - GENERAL MEETING of the Company will be held at the National Bank of Egypt, on Saturday, 22nd Junz, 1907. at 4 o'clock: p.m. precisely, for the purpose of receiving the Direetore’ Report and Balance Sheet for the year ended 3ist-Mareh,--1907, and fixing the Dividend, electing Directors. in the ‘place « of ‘those retiring, appointing Auditors. for the’ ensuing year and fixing - their and transacting the Ordinary~General Business of the Company.
Dated this 13th day of June 1907. By order of the Board, R-Q. HENRIQUES, General’ Manager. 2, Shareh Bank EL Warawt, Cairo.

N,B.—Shareholdets who hold Share Warrants to Bearer, and Whose naines are not on the Share Registers of the Company, are teminded that-if they wish to attend this ‘General Meeting of the Company, they must first deposit their Bedrer/Warrants together with a statement.in writing of their names and addresses, at any of the following Banks two clear days before the date of the Meeting, viz. : not later than the 20th June, 1907 : The National Bank of Egypt; The Bank of Egypt; The Anglo-Egyptian Bank Ltd. ; Ctedié Lyon- nais, or Imperial Ottoman Bank. The Share Warrants remaining so deposited until after the General Meeting shall h have been held. div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: LA SITUATION LOCALE.

La faiblesse n'a pas cessé pendant toute’ la semaine @’étre la note dominante de’ hotre marché ; chaque séance nouvelle a été Vocca- sion d'une accentuation de la baisse. Les choses en sont arrivées au point qu'il a été question parmi les courtiers de suspendre les affaires pour un certain laps de temps. On s’est arrété a un moyen terme et depuis hier, tant au Caire qu’a Alexandrie, les séances ont été réduites 4 une demi-heure pai jour. Ce temps suflit pour établir la cote et procéder aux -opérations les plas urgetites. Malheureusement ce temps suffit aussi~pour constater que les offres de vente, trés. nombreuses, ne trouvent pas aisément de contrepartie, ‘sinon pour éer- taines valeurs de font’ repos, et encore a des prix bas. Bref, c’est le tnarasme le plus com plet ; la crainte domitie et des bahques, dont les marges disparaissent, commencent a exé cuter certains clients. Un des principaux établissements financiers du pays, qui ‘avait obtenu une ordonnance en sa fayenr pour liqui der -une position, s'est’ vu dans Vimpossibilité den profiter, les cris et les sifflets expleine cor. beille ayant empéché de procéder a la vente des titres en question. Ce «qui vient encore compliquer la situation, ce sont les bruits: fil- cheux répandus depuis quelque temps a la bourse et qu’il est difficile, - pour ne pas dire impossible, de confirmer ou de démentir, tant quils n’auront pas regu une sanction offi- cielle. Pour mettre un terme a cette crise pénible on suggére des moyens plus ou moins efficaees, tels que de fermer la bourse, ete. D/autre part, on prend 4 partie le fameux syn- dicat ou consortium dont if a été tant parlé et dont la présence, an gré de beaucoup, tarde vraiment a se manifester. Qu’attend-il pour entrer en scéne ? Si c'est seulement |/s‘est formé, le pays ne Ini devra aucune reconnaissance ; les capitalistes, en effet, ne manquent pas'dans ‘le pays pour remplir ce role lucratif. Mais laissons le consortium. Comme c'est autant a une crise de confian- ce que nous avons affaire qu’d. une crise monétaire proprement dite, nous n’hésitons pas a nous rallier 4 Y'opinion de cenx qui pré tendent qu'il n'y a qu’a laisser les choses snivre leurs cours naturel ; tout “ce qu'on imagine pour y mettre obstacle ne sert qu’a-redoubler la méfiance et a précipiterles événements. La situation n’est dailleurs pas anssi désespérée que certains voudraient le faire croire, puis- que tout prospére en Egypte, coton, commerce, recettes de l’Etat, ete. ; seule la Bourse subit une crise fhomentan/e.

div.head: LES MARCHES EUROPEENS.
div.p: Soit que les ordres de vente proviennent @Egypte ou d’ailleurs, les valeurs égyptiennos témoignent aussi d’une baisse sensible. tant A Londres’ qu’a Paris. A Londres, la Daira, Agricole, la National Bank et'la Delta Light tombent respectivement de 15, 8$, 229 et 99 a 13}, 73, 193, et 94. A Paris, la Land Bank fléchit de 192 4 180, la Banque d’Athénes de 128 4 123 et le Crédit Franco Egyptien de 130 4 123. Le tdux privé d’escompte a Londres hausse de } a 3}, tandis que le taux officiel se maintient sans changement a 4% a Londres, 3} 4 Paris et 54 A Berlin. Le Con- $olidé Anglais regagne $484. La proportion de la réserve de la banque d’Angleterre aux engagements est de 47 %, en bénéfice de 4 sur la semaine flernitre. On voit par les cours ci- dessus que la situation des valeurs égyptiennes nest pas plus brillante en Enrope qu’ici. Cependant, notre correspondant de Londres nousinformait ce matin que les bas prix atteints par ces valeurs commengaient a attirer sériéu- sement I’attention des gros eapitalistes,

div.head: COMPAGNIE DU CANAL DE SUEZ
div.p: Du rapport qui vient d'être publié il ressort que le trafic du Canal de Suez, qui avait légèrement fléchi en 1905, s'est relevé en 1906 et a dépassé le niveau atteint en 1904, le plus élevé auquel il fût jusqu'alors parvenu. Aussi, tandis qu'il était prévu pour la détaxe une diminution de recettes de 10 millions, la moinsvalue est restée inférieure à 6 millions.

Les recettes totales de 1906 ont atteint | 111.989.122 fr. soit 5.319.073 fr. de moins qu'en 1905. Les dépenses totales, qui se sont élevées à 42.279.469 fr., ont dépassé de 1.295,285 | fr. celles de 1905. L'excédent des recettes sur les dépenses qui a été de 69.709.658 fr., a présenté en définitive, relativement à l'exer. eice 1905, nne diminution de 6.614.358 fr. Après prélèvement du 3% au profit de la réserve statutaire, cet excédent se trouve ramené à 67.618.363 fr., ce qui, avec le report de 1905, forme un total de 67.634 036 fr. Pour permettre la distribution du même dividende que l'année précédente, soit 141 fr., il a été I prélevé 3.800.000 fr. sur la réserve extraordi
naire, constituée à l'aide des bénéfices des deux derniers exercices.

Le prix de revient du Canal a été angmenté en 1906 de 6.435.744 fr., chiffre qui correspond aux travaux d'amélioration exécutés pendant l'année. La valeur de l'actif mobilier et immobilier s'est acerbe de 444.023 fr., chiffre correspondant à l'excédent des inscriptions de matériel nouveau sur les radiations de matériel hors d'usage. La réserve statutaire a bénéficié du 3% prélevé sur les recettes, ce qui en porte le total à 25.570.206 fr. La réserve extraordinaire å été, par contre, ramenée à 4.200.000 fr. à la suite du prélèvement de 3.800.000 fr. pour parfaire le divi. Idende.

Pendant l'année 1906, 3975 navires, représentant un tonnage de 13.445.504 tonnes, ont transité par le Canal. Relativement à 1905, il ressort une diminution de 141 navires et une augmentation de 311.399 tonnes. En raison de l'importance considérable que le développement de l'industrie automobile a donné an Commerce des
essences, leur passage par le Canal a été admis en principe, moyennant un ensemble de prescriptions de nature à assurer la sécurité du Canal.

La Compagnie a entrepris l'otablissement à Ismailia d'une distribution d'ear filtrée, analogue à celle qui existe à Port-Saïd et à Suez. Dans quelques mois les travaux seront terminés. Une campagne pour la destruction des moustiques a été également entreprise depuis quelques mois à Port-Said avec l'aide financière de la Compagnie. Les résultats sont déjà apppréciables.

Le Canal Maritime ainsi que le chenal de Port-Said ont été entretenus en bon état de navigabilité, en 1906, par l'exécution de! | 167,697 m3. de terrassements à sec et de 2,602,716 m3. de dragages. Les dragages d'en-1 tretien sont pouss's jusqu'à 10m. 50 de profondeur.
Les travaux d'amélioration ont été poussés avec activité. Ils comprennent principalement um élargissement de 8 m. au plafond depuis I le kil. 61 jusqu'à Suez, l'amélioration et la

rectification de la Courbe Asie de la gare du lac Timsah, l'élargissement à 100 m. 'an plafond aux débouchés nord et sud dans le grand lac Amer, le creusement de nouveaux bassins à Port-Said, le prolongement de la jetée Est, etc. Outre ces travaux en cours d'exécution, la Compagnie en envisage de nouveaux de la plus grande importance, entre autres la création de bassins intérieurs et l'elargissement du débouché du Canal.

Le rapatriement des troupes russes de Mandchourie a contribué à l'intensité du trafic 71 navires d'une jauge globale de 267,000 tonnes ont transporté 120,000 hommes. L'extension de la navigation' postale et des services de I cargo-boats a également concouru à la pros périté de la Compagnie.

Les héritiers de Negrelli avaient formé un pourvoi en cassation contre l'arrêt de 26 décembre 1905, par lequel la première chambre de la Cour d'Appel de Paris les avait déboutês de leur action en requête civile. La Chambte des requêtes, par un arrêt rendu le 18 décembre 1906, a rejeté ce pourvoi.

div.head: “INVESTMENTS.”
div.p:
“Investments” introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are “Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them”; “Theory of Successful Speculation”; “How to start an Account” ; “The Advantages of ‘Call Options’”; “Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities” ; “How to Invest in Mines”; “American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees”; “The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments” ; “General Principles for Investors” ; “Rules for Investors in Mines”; “General Principles for Speculators”; “Stock Exchange Terms,” being a glossary for Market Operators; “Stock Exchange Parlance”; “Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money,” and “Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities.”
“Investments” (148 pages) sent Post Free on mentioning “Egyptian Gazette.”
LONDON & PARIS EXCHANGE LIMITED, GENERAL BANKERS. BASILDON HOUSE, BANK, LONDON, E.C.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA WATER COMPANY LTD.
div.p: Avis est donné par la présente qu'une Deuxième Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire de la Compagnie aura lien au Bureau de la Compagnie à Alexandrie le Jeudi le 4 Juillet 1907 à 4 b. p.m. pour confirmer les résolutions approuvées à l'Assemblée Générale Extraor dinaire le 11 Juin 1907.
1. L'augmentation du Capital de la Compagnie par la création de 20,000 nouvelles actions de £5 nominales chacune, exclusivementoffertes aux Actionnaires.
2. De donner pouvoirs au Conseil d'Administration d'émettre ces actions en totalité ou en partie, au moment et au prix qu'il jugera opportun dans l'intérêt de la Compagnie.

Pour assister ou se faire représenter à cette Assemblée, MM. les propriétaires d'actions au porteur sont informés que, conformément aux Statuts, leurs titres doivent être déposés à l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank, Ltd. à Alexandrie, au moins trois jours franes, avant l'Assemblée du chez Messrs. Barclay and Company Ltd. 1, Pall Mall East, London. S.W., à Londres 14 jours francs, avant l'Assemblée.
Par ordre du Conseil d'Administration,
H.R.C. BLAGDEN 30475-5-3 Directeur.

div.p: AVIS

L'Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance da Publie qu'elle recevra jusqu'au vingt juin prochain, à midi au plus tard, des offres pour la fourniture de balsis en Samar," soit 10,000 (dix-mille) emmanchés et 3,000 (trois mille) sans manches. Des échantillons devront être koumis en même temps que les offres LliTraison se faite france dans les Magasins de l'Administration à Gabhary Alexandre Les Conditions Générales de cette fourniture peo vent être consulties su Bare Central du Service des Magasins à Boulae (Caire) et aux Magasins de Gabbary (Alexandre tous les jours de neuf heures de matin à une heure p.i. le Dimanches et jours ferits exceptes.

Un quart de la quantité des balais et de ches est livrer immédiatement; un quart de la quantité totale des balais emmanches et de ceux sans manches est a livrer dans deux mois et le reste sera livré quatre mois april commande
Pour etre mis à concourir le soumissione maire devrs vener, au préalable, à la Cainer

de l'Administration, à titre de dépôt provisire, une somme de LE 20 (livres Egyptiennes vingt). Le soumissionnaire déclaré sdjadicataire devra parfaire cette somme jusqu'à concurrence da 10 % (dix pour cent) du mom tant de l'offre agrón.

Les offres devront être accompagnie d'une feuille de papier timbré de trente milliemes ainsi que de rece constatant le venement da cautionnement provisoire surisé. Elles seront adresses par la Poste vous pli recom mandé à :
Monsieur le Directeur Général des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Le Caire
et sous double enveloppe, l'intérieure portant la suscription suivante : "Offre pour Poumitare de Balsis."
L'Administfation ne s'engage pas accep ter l'offre la plus basse, ni à donner saite ex soumissions présentées. Elle se serve le droit de diviser la commande

div.head: Notice to Advertisers.

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905

A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.

This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic

THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,
